TopicTitle: Ways to convince people that the Moon landings were real

Articles.Content: Hi everyone, I just watched a video of the moon landings. They actually made me feel proud of humanity, but that feeling was completely erased when I looked at the comment section. A bunch of idiots were saying that the Moon landings were fake, and I tried to argue with them, but they just mocked me. Thus, I want to figure out how to convince at least a few of them that the landings were real. Please help me come up with ideas.
There is no one easy argument to persuade people. Different people have different reasons for not believing it so only varied arguments will convince them otherwise.
It's usually pointless, any attempt is just proof of the conspiracy.

If it was YouTube then... Well. Place is a festering troll pit. But reguardless don't even bother. Even if it's someone in real life. These nutcase conspiracy theorists cannot be convinced with any amount of proof or logic. These people know everything about the conspiracy, but nothing about space flight. Or whatever it is there conspiring against.

... If your really looking for a laugh go over to the flat earth society. ( yes ... That exists. )
There's a saying about YouTube comments - Don't.
But the Moon doesn't exist. The government just made a hologram to fool us.

But the Moon doesn't exist. The government just made a hologram to fool us.

I see what you did there.

But seriously though, if the government made such a hologram to be seen by the whole world, that in itself is amazing technology.

In '08 Mythbusters devoted an entire episode to the Moon hoax conspiracy and busted it 100%.

http://mythbustersresults.com/nasa-moon-landing

And if it really was a hoax. If it was all filmed in a studio. Why haven't we gone there again?

If you believe the Apollo landings are a hoax you're an idiot!

But as with any claim of this sort, keep asking questions of them. Don't assert anything, but try to make them think. You'll usually only get a few questions in and they'll begin to falter. The most likely outcome is that they'll realise they can't answer you and just resort to calling you a shill (or worse) and run away triumphantly, but very rare occasions they admit they can't answer and will think critically. Generally, if someone has the gift of critical thought they don't believe conspiracy theories in the first place.

Ask things like "What would 'they' have to gain by doing it?" & "What is that supposed to prove?". Put the ball in their court, and it'll become apparent all they can do is stand there and dribble.
